item.title: Recommended Podcasts
item.dc:creator: mschweihs
item.content:encoded:
I have a 45 minute commute to work, one-way and I try to make the most of that time by listening to audio books and podcasts. Here is a current list of the podcasts I am following:

Raw Data

This is a Stanford podcast about how big data and cyber systems are transforming our world. Produced by Worldview Stanford and supported by the Stanford Cyber Initiative. They have finished their first season with 11 episodes that are about 30 minutes each and plan on beginning season two at the end of the summer. This is a well produced show that delivers news and highlights of current events relating to big data.

Talk Python To Me

Talk Python to Me is a weekly podcast hosted by Michael Kennedy. The show covers a wide array of Python topics as well as many related topics (e.g. MongoDB, AngularJS, DevOps). The format is a casual 45 minute conversation with industry experts. This podcast is also well produced and edited making it an easy listen. He regularly interviews people who are making major contributions to the open source python community such as an interview with Donald Stufft, who works for HP and is focused on improving Python Packaging through pip and PYPI. Or a recent interview with entrepreneur Scott Clark who developed SigOpt, an "optimization platform for everything" using machine learning and data science.

Data Skeptic

Data Skeptic is a podcast that alternates between short mini episodes and longer interviews. For the mini-episodes, Kyle and Linh Da explore basic data science concepts. Longer interviews feature practitioners and experts on interesting topics related to data, all through the eye of scientific skepticism.

A16z

Andreessen Horowitz backs bold entrepreneurs who move fast, think big, and are committed to building the next major franchises in technology. Founded by Marc Andreessen and Ben Horowitz, the firm provides entrepreneurs with access to expertise and insights in innovation, executive and technical talent, market intelligence, policy and regulatory affairs, business development, and marketing and brand-building.

Linear Digressions

Linear Digressions is a Machine Learning and Data Science podcast that's hosted by an experimental physicist and web developer who make hot topics in data science much more accessible than academic papers.

Partially Derivative

This a fun podcast where the co-hosts drink beer and talk about silly data science topics. I often find myself laughing out loud listening to their banter.

Data Science at Home

A podcast about data science by Francesco, a data scientist from Italy. He has an international perspective and interviews data scientists from around the world

Rational Security

Rational Security is a weekly foreign policy and national security roundup. Shane Harris of the Daily Beast shoots the breeze with Benjamin Wittes and Tamara Cofman Wittes, both of the Brookings Institution, on surveillance, the Middle East, and national security politics.

The Digital Analytics Power Hour

From the site: "Attend any conference for any topic and you will hear people saying after that the best and most informative discussions happened in the bar after the show. Read any business magazine and you will find an article saying something along the lines of "Business Analytics is the hottest job category out there, and there is a significant lack of people, process and best practice." In this case the conference was eMetrics, the bar was….multiple, and the attendees were Michael Helbling, Tim Wilson and Jim Cain (Co-Host Emeritus). After a few pints and a few hours of discussion about the cutting edge of digital analytics, they realized they might have something to contribute back to the community. This podcast is one of those contributions. Each episode is a closed topic and an open forum - the goal is for listeners to enjoy listening to Michael and Tim share their thoughts and experiences and hopefully take away something to try at work the next day. We hope you enjoy listening to the Digital Analytics Power Hour.

Data Stories

Data Stories is a podcast similar to The Data Skeptic Podcast. Their focus tends to be a bit more on data visualization. A great addition for listeners keenly interested in data science.

item.title: Using Octave for Machine Learning
item.dc:creator: mschweihs
item.content:encoded: First things first: Installing Octave! Check out this quick tutorial for configuring Octave correctly on a Mac OS X: http://liqul.github.io/notebook/2016/03/install-octave-on-osx-ei-capitan-10113

item.title: Olympic Feathers
item.dc:creator: mschweihs
item.content:encoded:
Olympics Feathers - All ±5000 gold medallists visualized
Sourced through Scoop.it from: nbremer.github.io Olympic Feathers is a wonderful example of the possibilities of Data Visualization and Data journalism. Looking for the patterns, it is interesting to note which continent has dominated which sports throughout history. By creating a visualization, we can easily spot these trends that would otherwise take painstaking research to unravel. Luckily, Nadieh Bremer, an astronomer turned data scientist, has gone through the painstaking process herself and left us with a Peacock-feather inspired story and some hidden gems to uncover. Check it out! Also, check out her other inspiring visualizations at http://www.visualcinnamon.com/. Cheers!

item.title: JuPyTeR Notebook Python Workflow
item.dc:creator: mschweihs
item.content:encoded:
I am working on an assignment for my Data Science Programming Class and I realize that I have a systematic method of opening windows and setting up desktops for the upcoming work. First of all, I am using dual screens and my operating system (OS X 10.11.16) lets me set up multiple desktops on each screen. This is a pretty common thing for operating systems, but on my mac, I can three-finger-swipe up, left, or right and get to the screen I want very quickly.  I love doing this because it keeps me organized and I don't have to minimize anything....I just put all of my main stuff on its own desktop and swipe back and forth. So here's the set up (not optimized yet....getting there):

Monitor Left

Desktop 1: Browser open with workspaces:
  • Working Directory
  • Active Jupiter Notebook(s)
Desktop 2: Anaconda Navigator
  • in case I need to install any packages into the environment while I'm working on the Jupyter notebook. I could do this via the CLI, but the GUI is quicker and I can trust Anaconda to install while I keep working. During this assignment, I did have to install the spyder IDE to the environment that I was using.
Desktop 3: Blank
  • I don't know if this is just a Mac thing, but there is always a blank desktop ready to go on each screen.

Monitor Right

Desktop 4: Another Browser with References Ready to Go!
  • Python 3 Online Course
  • D2L Course Website
  • dotslashmaggie.wordpress.com  :-D!
  • Google (at the ready!)
Desktop 4: spyder Python IDE
  • You definitely need some kind of IDE open while working with Jupyter Notebooks. It makes troubleshooting so much easier in my opinion. The notebook will not give you all of the error output. You can also take advantage of features such as tab completion in the IDE. spyder suites my needs. It has a console/terminal area, variables, help-window-pane, and editor. It's very customizable.
  • I initially had a terminal open too, but found that I could open a terminal session in the spyder workspace which came in handy when I had to switch from a 2.7.x to the 3.5.2 environment that my Jupyter notebook was running
   
Desktop 5: GitHub Desktop
  • Again, I could do this from the command line...I would actually love to learn more about Git CLI so I can be a CLI ninja....but the GUI is easy to use and gets the job done quick. It also encourages you to commit often and make comments because the button and text box are in your face like "USE ME"!! Basically, I keep this window up so I remember to commit often and makes meaningful comments.
Desktop 6: Junk Drawer
  • Finally, this screen has all the little random stuff that I may open along the way...calculator, finder, etc.

Workflow

My workflow for this assignment was smooth. We were just doing some basic string manipulation: pig latin translator and some work with "encrypted" files. So all txt files and ascii characters...VERY simple stuff. the workflow consisted of writing the sudo code in the spyder editor and beginning to import the data and do the initial data manipulation of formatting all characters to lowers, creating a few dictionaries, etc. I started doing the initial steps in the iPython console of spyder and the reason for that is because I am very new to python so even the most basic tasks take some finagling and research. That's how I learn. Once I have the syntax correct, I move it into the JuPyTeR notebook and run it to make sure there are no new errors...typically there are not, unless I have a path error or have forgotten to import a package. There is a lot of back and forth between the two systems. The error output is richer in the IDE. Also, you have the ability to use tab completion and the help-viewer in the IDE. jupyter notebooks are great for creating reproducible research. Notebooks are an excellent way to share information with other scientists, presenting information, and teaching data science concepts.

Call to Action

There is so much technology and so many different ways to organize our technology stacks, how do we decide what to use and how to use it? I would love to learn more about simple productive solutions for data science productivity!

item.title: 50 UNIX / Linux Sysadmin Tutorials
item.dc:creator: mschweihs
item.content:encoded:
via 50 UNIX / Linux Sysadmin Tutorials The great thing about *Nix is that resources are Timeless in a sense. I have been holding onto this article for about a year and I am going to archive it here on dotslashmaggie because I like the content. My Favorite TidBit: 3 sysadmin rules you can't (and shouldn't) break: (paraphrased by maggie) 1. Backup Everything and validate! 2. Master the Command Line....Yes! 3. Automate Everything (and become lazy) (because you know what they say about a good sysadmin!) Don't forget the "Golden Rule": Don't try anything crazy on friday! There are really so many good nuggets of wisdom in the article, mostly tutorials:
  • dd backup
  • 15 rsync command examples
  • 10 netstat examples
  • Install phpMyAdmin
  • Setup Squid to control internet access
  • Add new swap Space!!
  • Install and configure snort
  • mount and view ISOs
  • ifconfig examples
  • oracle db startup and shutdown
  • list hardware specs using ls+hw
  • template to track your hardware assets >>>think COOP!
  • Logical Volume Manager >>> I had 3 boot disks fail this year!
  • rotate logs automatically >>>Why am I not doing this yet?
item.excerpt:encoded: "The Geek Stuff" Blog has collected 50 UNIX / Linux sysadmin related tutorials that they posted in 2015. The great thing about *Nix is that resources are Timeless in a sense. Keep this for future reference and read it whenever you get free time.

item.title: Open Source Data Science Resource List
item.dc:creator: mschweihs
item.content:encoded:
I can't get enough of the free open source data science resources, classes, tutorials, data-sets, projects, software, etc. Please find here, my definitive collection of data science resources. Soon, I hope to send this to a github repo and then you can fork it from there. For now, here is the beginning of my list, to be updated continuously. (Last Updated 9/1/2017) Please leave suggestions as well!

MOOCs and Courses

  1. https://ocw.mit.edu/index.htm : MIT OpenCourseWare, ie. a treasure trove of free learning. For Data Science material, I recommend searching for courses by topic and diving into Engineering -> Computer Science -> Data Mining. That topic alone has over 30 undergraduate and graduate courses.
  2. https://www.edx.org
  3. https://see.stanford.edu/Course/ : Stanford Engineering Everywhere offers free Stanford courses online in Computer Science, Artificial Intelligence and Linear Systems and Optimization.
  4. https://www.coursera.org/ : Coursera partners with top universities to offer classes online. You can take them in "audit" mode, where you do not take tests and do not earn a certificate, but you still have access to all of the class materials. If you need something to show for your work, then you can purchase the certificate option for $79 or $49/month. A few that you can take for free:
    1. https://www.coursera.org/learn/game-theory-1
    2. https://www.coursera.org/learn/crypto
    3. https://www.coursera.org/learn/datasciencemathskills: Data science courses contain math—no avoiding that! This course is designed to teach learners the basic math you will need in order to be successful in almost any data science math course and was created for learners who have basic math skills but may not have taken algebra or pre-calculus.
    4. https://www.coursera.org/learn/bayesian-statistics: This course introduces the Bayesian approach to statistics, starting with the concept of probability and moving to the analysis of data. We will learn about the philosophy of the Bayesian approach as well as how to implement it for common types of data.
    5. https://www.coursera.org/learn/mcmc-bayesian-statistics: This is the second of a two-course sequence introducing the fundamentals of Bayesian statistics. It builds on the course Bayesian Statistics: From Concept to Data Analysis, which introduces Bayesian methods through use of simple conjugate models. Real-world data often require more sophisticated models to reach realistic conclusions.
    6. https://www.coursera.org/learn/machine-learning: Machine learning is the science of getting computers to act without being explicitly programmed. In the past decade, machine learning has given us self-driving cars, practical speech recognition, effective web search, and a vastly improved understanding of the human genome. M
    7. https://www.coursera.org/learn/neural-networks: Learn about artificial neural networks and how they're being used for machine learning, as applied to speech and object recognition, image segmentation, modeling language and human motion, etc.
    8. https://www.coursera.org/learn/social-media-data-analytics: Utilize various Application Programming Interface (API) services to collect data from different social media sources such as YouTube, Twitter, and Flickr.
  5. http://www.cs171.org/2017/index.html : Intro to Data Visualization class from Harvard
  6. https://github.com/datasciencemasters/go: Another Collection of Open Courses and some for-purchase recommendations

Game-based Learning

  1. https://www.dataquest.io/: Free option that does not expire and offers all-in-one curriculum for learning skills to become a data analyst, scientist, or engineer. Pay for a subscription to access more support and resources. Python based projects.
  2. https://checkio.org: Interactively learn python or java script.

Search for Data Science Jobs

  1. https://www.upwork.com/o/jobs/browse/skill/data-science/: Freelance Data Science Projects
  2. https://www.freelancer.com/jobs/data-science/: More Freelance data science
  3. https://remoteok.io/remote-work-statistics: Remote Data Science Work
  4. https://www.crossover.com/#index: Remote Data Science Work
  5. https://www.ndash.co: Pitch data journalism ideas to companies
  6. http://www.kdnuggets.com/jobs/index.html
  7. http://www.analytictalent.datasciencecentral.com

Academic Journals

  1. http://www.jds-online.com/about: Journal of Data Science
  2. http://journals.plos.org/plosone/
  3. http://www.mdpi.com/journal/data: Open access 'Data in Science' Journal
  4. https://datascience.codata.org: The CODATA Data Science Journal is a peer-reviewed, open access, electronic journal, publishing papers on the management, dissemination, use and reuse of research data and databases across all research domains, including science, technology, the humanities and the arts. The scope of the journal includes descriptions of data systems, their implementations and their publication, applications, infrastructures, software, legal, reproducibility and transparency issues, the availability and usability of complex datasets, and with a particular focus on the principles, policies and practices for open data.
  5. https://link.springer.com/journal/41060: International Journal of Data Science and Analytics: Data-driven scientific discovery is a key emerging paradigm driving research innovation and industrial development in domains such as business, social sci­ence, the Internet of Things, and cloud computing. The field encompasses the larger ar­eas of data analytics, machine learning, and managing big data, while related new sci­entific chal­lenges range from data capture, creation, storage, search, sharing, analysis, and vis­ualization.
  6. https://www.nature.com/sdata/: Scientific Data

Data Sets

  1. https://www.data.gov
  2. https://data.world
  3. http://jmcauley.ucsd.edu/data/amazon/: amazon review data (great for sentiment analysis and NLP)
  4. https://snap.stanford.edu/data/index.html: Standford Large Network Dataset Collection
  5. https://www.citibikenyc.com/system-data: Citi Bike data from NYC
  6. https://www.kaggle.com
item.excerpt:encoded: Please find here, my definitive collection of data science resources.

item.title: How to Switch Environments in Anaconda
item.dc:creator: mschweihs
item.content:encoded: It's been a few months since I've logged into JuPyTer notebooks and when I fired it up from the Anaconda Navigator, I only had Python 2 notebooks available! Of course, a quick google search was all it took to figure out how to switch environments. Here is the article that jogged my memory: python - jupyter notebook running kernel in different env - Stack Overflow.

item.title: How to Switch Environments in Anaconda
item.dc:creator: mschweihs
item.content:encoded:
It's been a few months since I've logged into JuPyTer notebooks and when I fired it up from the Anaconda Navigator, I only had Python 2 notebooks available! Of course, a quick google search was all it took to figure out how to switch environments. Here is the article that jogged my memory: [python - jupyter notebook running kernel in different env - Stack Overflow].
Run the following command to see what environments you have configured in your local anaconda installation
In [ ]:
dom310:~ maggie$ conda info --envs
# conda environments:
#
DS710                    /Users/maggie/anaconda2/envs/DS710
root                  *  /Users/maggie/anaconda2
Use the following command to activate an environment
In [ ]:
dom310:~ maggie$ source activate DS710
And one more to fire up your JuPyTer Notebook
In [ ]:
(DS710) dom310:~ maggie$ jupyter notebook
